title: Introduction
content:
Deploying a Web High Availability System with Auto Scaling and Load Balancer on AWS
In this workshop, you will learn how to deploy a high availability web system using EC2, Auto Scaling Group (ASG), and Application Load Balancer (ALB) within the VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) environment on AWS.
The deployment follows a Multi-AZ (Availability Zone) architecture to ensure system stability even if one zone experiences failure.
üéØ Workshop Objectives ‚úÖ Configure VPC, Subnet, Route Table, Internet Gateway according to best practices ‚úÖ Create an Application Load Balancer to distribute traffic ‚úÖ Set up an Auto Scaling Group to automatically add/remove EC2 instances as load increases/decreases ‚úÖ Ensure the system is self-healing and can scale flexibly üß© System Architecture Analysis 1. VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) A logically isolated virtual network in AWS Allows creation of subnets to segment and control access Manages traffic routing via Route Tables 2. Internet Gateway Provides internet connectivity for the VPC Attached to public subnets so that ALB or EC2 can be accessed from the outside 3. Public Subnet Hosts the Application Load Balancer (ALB) Has routes to the Internet Gateway Entry point for traffic from the Internet 4. Private Subnet Hosts EC2 instances (backend applications) No direct route to the Internet ‚Üí increases security Can be combined with NAT Gateway if outbound traffic is needed 5. Application Load Balancer (ALB) Receives HTTP/HTTPS requests from clients Distributes traffic to EC2 instances in the Auto Scaling Group via Target Group 6. Auto Scaling Group (ASG) Manages the lifecycle of EC2 instances Automatically scales in/out based on metrics like CPU usage or number of requests Always maintains an appropriate number of EC2 instances as configured 7. EC2 Instances Servers running the web application Automatically created/terminated by ASG Can be deployed across multiple AZs for fault tolerance 8. Target Group A list of EC2 instances to which ALB distributes traffic Integrated Health Checks to ensure traffic is only routed to healthy instances ‚úÖ Benefits of the Architecture üü¢ Highly Available: EC2 instances available across multiple AZs for redundancy üìà Scalable: Automatically scales and optimizes cost based on traffic üîÅ Automated: No manual EC2 instance management required üîê Secure: Backend components are isolated within private subnets üìå Conclusion This architecture serves as a foundation for modern web systems on AWS.
The workshop will guide you step-by-step to configure, deploy, and test the model according to real-world and production standards.

title: Security Group for ALB
content: Create Security Group for ALB On the EC2 page, find and select Security Groups in the left-hand menu. Click Create Security Group In the Create Security Group interface under Basic Details Name: enter SG-ALB Description: enter Allow HTTP from internet to ALB VPC: select workshop as in previous steps In the Inbound section, select HTTP as shown Outbound remains unchanged. Review and click Create Security Group

title: Application Load Balancing
content:
Create an Application Load Balancer On the EC2 page, find and select Load Balancers in the left-hand navigation panel. Click Create Load Balancer On the Create Load Balancer interface, choose Application Load Balancer Under Basic Configuration
Name: enter workshop-ALB Scheme: select Internet Facing Load balancer IP address type: select IPv4 Under Network Mapping VPC: choose workshop AZs: select both Availability Zones of the two Public Subnets In Security Groups, select the previously created SG-ALB Under Listeners and Routing, choose the workshop-tg target group created in section 4 Click Create Load Balancer If created successfully, you will see a screen like the one below

title: Create Public Subnet
content:
Create Public Subnet Click Subnets Click Create subnet On the Create subnet page: Under VPC ID, select workshop In the Subnet name field, enter Public Subnet 1 In the Availability Zone field, select the first Availability Zone In the IPv4 CIDR block field, enter 10.10.1.0/24 Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click Create subnet
Select Public Subnet 1
Click Actions Click Edit subnet settings Select Enable auto-assign public IPv4 address Click Save Create Public Subnet 2 similarly with IPv4 CIDR block: 10.10.2.0/24

title: Preparation
content: Preparation 1. VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) Create an isolated virtual network environment for EC2. Control IP ranges, divide subnets, and manage connectivity. 2. Subnets Public Subnet: Hosts instances that need internet access. Private Subnet: Hosts instances that do not require direct internet access. 3. Internet Gateway (IGW) Allows the public subnet to access the internet. Attach the IGW to the VPC to enable outbound connectivity. 4. Route Tables Public Route Table: Routes 0.0.0.0/0 through the IGW. Private Route Table: Keeps private instances within the internal network. 5. Security Group Acts as a firewall for EC2: Allow inbound ports 22 (SSH), 80 (HTTP), and 443 (HTTPS) for public instances. Allow internal communication between private and public EC2 as needed.

title: Create EC2 and Test Connection
content:
Create EC2 In the EC2 console, click Launch Templates on the left. Then click Create launch template.
In the Create launch template page:
In Name, enter workshop In Description, enter Template for workshop
Under Application and OS Images:
Choose Quick Start, then select Amazon Linux In AMI, choose as shown in the image
For Instance type, we will use t2.micro for this workshop (cost-effective)
Next is Key pair:
If you already have a key pair, you can reuse it. If not, click Create
A popup will appear like the image below
Name the Key pair as workshop-1, select Type: RSA, and File format: .pem
Click Create
After creating, choose the newly created Key pair as shown
In Network settings, under Security Groups, select Public Subnet - workshop, which is the Security Group created earlier
Scroll down to Advanced Details, under User data input the following:
#!/bin/bash sudo yum update sudo yum install httpd -y sudo systemctl start httpd echo “ We’re on the $(hostname -I) ” | sudo tee /var/www/html/index.html Review everything and click Create After successful creation, a confirmation message will appear as shown
Go back to the main dashboard and select Dashboard
Click Launch instance from template
Choose the Template you created in Step 9
In Network Setting, under Subnet, select Public Subnet 1
Scroll down and click Launch instance
Once launched successfully, you will see one running Instance in the EC2 main page
Click on the newly launched Instance
Copy the Auto-assigned IP address Open a new tab in your browser and test it Example: http://3.25.255.86
If successful, the server will display the Private IPv4 address

title: Create Internet Gateways
content: Create Internet Gateways Click Internet Gateways. Click Create internet gateway. On the Create internet gateway page: In the Name tag field, enter Internet GateWay workshop. Click Create internet gateway. After successful creation, click Actions. Click Attach to VPC. On the Attach to VPC page: In the Available VPCs field, select workshop. Click Attach internet gateway. Verify the attachment was successful as shown below.

title: Create Route Tables
content: Create Route Tables Next, we will create a custom Route table to associate with Public Subnet 1. Click Route tables. Click Create Route table. On the Create Route table page: In the Name field, enter Route table-Public-workshop. In the VPC field, select workshop. Click Create Route table. After successfully creating the Route table, a notification will appear as shown: Click Edit routes. On the Edit routes page: Click Add route. In the Destination field, enter 0.0.0.0/0 In the Target field, select the Internet Gateway you just created. Click Save changes. Click the Subnet associations tab. Click Edit subnet associations to associate the custom route table you just created with Public Subnet 1. On the Edit subnet associations page: Check Public Subnet. Click Save associations. Verify that the Route table has been associated with Public Subnet and that the route to the internet points to the Internet Gateway as shown below.

title: Create Target Groups
content:
Create Target Groups In the EC2 interface, find Target Groups on the left-hand sidebar. Click Create target groups.
In the Create interface:
Set Type to Instance Enter workshop-tg as the Name
Next: Choose IPv4 for IP address type Select workshop for VPC Choose HTTP1 for Protocol version
Click Next
Click Create target group
When created successfully, a green notification will appear as shown

title: Application Load Balancers
content:
Application Load Balancer (ALB) Main Function:
Distributes HTTP/HTTPS traffic across multiple EC2 instances in an Auto Scaling Group.
Advantages:
Supports routing based on URL paths and hostnames (e.g., /api, /admin) Performs health checks on EC2 instances Supports SSL termination (HTTPS encryption) Automatically scales with user demand Usage in Auto Scaling:
Ensures even and continuous traffic distribution to EC2 instances created or removed by the Auto Scaling Group.

title: Create Private Subnet
content: Create Private Subnet Click Subnets. Click Create subnet. Same as in the Public section. On the Create subnet page: In the VPC ID field, select workshop. In the Subnet name field, enter Private Subnet 1. In the Availability Zone field, choose the first Availability Zone. In the IPv4 CIDR block field, enter 10.10.3.0/24. Scroll to the bottom of the page, click Create subnet. Create Private Subnet 2 in the same way with IPv4 CIDR block as 10.10.4.0/24

title: Create Security Groups
content:
Create Security Group for Public Subnet Go to the VPC service console Click Security Group. Click Create security group. In the Security group name field, enter Public Subnet - workshop. You are recommended to include SG in the name. In the Description field, enter Allow SSH access to developers. In the VPC field, click the X icon to re-select the workshop VPC you created for this lab. In the Inbound rules section:
Click Add rule. Choose SSH, HTTP, and All ICMP - IPv4 as shown below.
Leave the Outbound rule as default, scroll down.
Click Create security group. Create Security Group for Private Subnet Go back to the Security groups list. Click Create security group. In the Security group name field, enter Private Subnet - workshop. In the Description field, enter Allows SSH and Ping for servers in private subnet. In the VPC field, click the X icon to re-select the workshop VPC created for this lab. In the Inbound rules section: Click Add rule. Select SSH and All ICMP - IPv4. For SSH, choose the Security Group you just created for the Public subnet. Leave the Outbound rule as default, scroll down. Click Create security group.

title: Experiment
content:
Go back to the Instance section, and you will see an EC2 Instance that was just created by the ASG
Click on it and test it like in step 3.15, and the result will be similar to image 3.16
Go back to the Auto Scaling Group page, and select workshop-ASG
On the workshop-ASG page, click Edit
When the form appears, change Min from 1 to 2 and Desired capacity from 1 to 2. Click Update
Go back to the Instance section, and you will see that another server has been created because we just increased the count to 2
Go to the Target Groups section, and on the main page, select workshop-tg
On the workshop-tg page, you will see 2 instances. These instances were created by the ASG and attached to the Target Group. At this point, the ALB will distribute traffic based on the Target Group
Switch to the Load Balancer section and select workshop-ALB
Copy the DNS name and paste it into your browser’s address bar
Press F5 repeatedly to observe the load balancing between the two instances

title: Delete Resources
content:
On the Auto Scaling Group page, select workshop-ASG, click Actions, and choose Delete
A confirmation prompt will appear, type delete and click Delete
On the Load Balancers page, select workshop-ALB, click Actions, and choose Delete load balancer
A confirmation prompt will appear, type confirm and click Delete
On the Target Groups page, select workshop-tg, click Actions, and choose Delete
A confirmation will appear, click Delete
Go back to the main VPC page, select workshop, click Actions, and choose Delete VPC
A confirmation prompt will appear, type delete and click Delete
Go to the Internet Gateways page, click Actions, and choose Detach from VPC
Type detach and click Detach internet gateway
Repeat the above steps and choose Delete internet gateway
Type delete and click Delete internet gateway
